prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Evolution of Angular Momentum From Cores to Disks

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: One baseband is used for C18O(2-1) and 13CO(2-1). C18O is justified above. 13CO is optically thicker than C18O, and thus is good for tracing scales slightly larger than C18O, and is complimentary to C18O. One baseband is used for N2D+(3-2) and 12CO(2-1). N2D+ is abundant where CO is depleted, and therefore is good for tracing outer envelopes where temperatures are below the sublimation temperature of CO at 20 K. 12CO(2-1) will be used for detecting outflows, which will help to determine the direciton of rotational axis. One baseband is used for H2CO(3_0,3 - 2_0,2) and SO(6-5); they are the secondary lines in the study. H2CO and SO are both good tracers for inner envelopes of protostellar cores and disks (Maret et al. 2004). SO traces structures produced by shocks in disks (Ohashi et al. 2014). One baseband is used for dust continuum. From the results of MASSES, we expect 1.5 km/s for the C18O linewidth. With the proposed spectral setup, we will have 18 resolution elements, which are sufficient to resolve the kinematics.

In this proposal we aim to study gas kinematics and specific angular momentum of protostars at a 200 AU scale with ALMA. Our sources in Perseus are at a distance of 230 pc, and the requested angular resolution of 0.9 arcsec (200 AU) is well suited for our science goal. We will combine the ALMA data with the data from the SMA, which capture scales larger than 10 arcsecs. The OT does not recommend ACA for our requested largest angular scale of 10 arcsecs.

We plan to observe C18O(2-1) at Band 6 as the main tracer to probe gas kinematics in the inner envelopes of protostars. C18O(2-1) is frozen out in the cold, outter envelopes and is released back to the gas phase in inner envelopes of protostars(> 20 K; Jorgensen et al. 2002). Several studies have shown that C18O is a good tracer for gas kinematics in the inner envelopes to disks of protostars (e.g., Murrillo et al. 2013). From the SMA large survey, MASSES, we obtained C18O(2-1) detections with a ~4" beam. The measurements show that the sources typically have a peak flux density of ~ 3.5 K. We request a RMS of 0.43 K to reach a S/N ~ 10. Based on the results from MASSES, the sources have 1.5 km/s linewidths in general. To fully resolve the gas motions, we request a spectral resolution of 70.56 MHz (0.096 km/s), and a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (80 km/s) to capture the full emission. We have chosen to average the spectral channels to reduce the data rate without affecting the desired spectral resolution and science goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Angular momentum determines the initial conditions for disk formation and has implications on the properties of multiple systems. We aim to better understand how angular momentum influences the scale for dynamical collapse, shapes the degree of fragmentation and separation in multiple systems, and provides constraints for numerical simulations. We propose to study the specific angular momentum in the inner envelopes of ten Class 0 sources at ~200 AU scales. By combining the ALMA measurements of specific angular momentum with two large surveys from the SMA and GBT, we will be able to trace the evolution of specific angular momentum from 20000 AU to 200 AU for the first time. Also, our sample of ten sources, which consists of six single systems and four binary systems, will allow us to investigate and compare the conditions in these two types of different systems. ALMA provides an unique opportunity to study the gas kinematics down to 200 AU scale with its unprecedented sensitivity, thus providing key information on the transition from envelopes to disks.
